questions.question: Which of the following statements about the spaces of the larynx is true?

options.A: The paraglottic space is located above the infrahyoid epiglottis.
options.B: The preepiglottic space is continuous with the paraglottic space.
options.C: Reinke's space is located between the quadrangular membrane and the thyroid cartilage.
options.D: Tumours in the preepiglottic space typically extend into the neck via the cricothyroid membrane.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The preepiglottic space is continuous with the paraglottic space. Explanation: The preepiglottic space is continuous with the paraglottic space. Spaces of the Larynx: Space Location Boundaries Contents Clinical Relevance Preepiglottic Space (Space of Boyer) Anterior and superior to the infrahyoid epiglottis (Option A ruled out) Anterior: Upper thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane Superior: Hyoepiglottic ligament Posterior: Quadrangular membrane Areolar tissue, fat, lymphatics Can be invaded by cancers of the supraglottic larynx or base of the tongue Paraglottic Space Lateral to the laryngeal ventricle Lateral: Thyroid cartilage Medial: Quadrangular membrane and ventricle Inferomedial: Conus elasticus Posterior: Piriform fossa mucosa N/A Tumours may extend into the neck via the cricothyroid membrane (Option D ruled out) Reinke's Space Beneath the epithelium of the vocal cords (Option C ruled out) Bounded by arcuate lines running from the vocal process of arytenoid to the anterior commissure Subepithelial connective tissue Oedema in this space results in Reinke's oedema, causing vocal cord swelling. Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Page 334

questions.question: A 35-year-old teacher presents with hoarseness and vocal fatigue over the past few months. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral lesions at the junction of the anterior 1/3rds and posterior 2/3rds of the vocal cords. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Vocal Nodule Explanation: Vocal nodules are caused by chronic vocal abuse , commonly seen in teachers or singers. They are typically bilateral and located at the junction of the anterior and posterior thirds of the vocal cords, matching the patient's presentation. Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule) Vocal Polyp Cause Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers. ) Sudden Vocal abuse like shouting (Men in the age group of 30-50 years). Heavy smoking Laterality Bilateral or symmetrical Unilateral Location Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord. Same as vocal nodules. Appearance Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage Smooth and pedunculated. Symptoms Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation. Hoarseness of voice and diplophonia (double voice due to different vibrating frequencies of two vocal cords) Large polyps- dyspnea, stridor, choking. Treatment Initially, voice rest. If it fails - microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament Speech therapy Microscopic excision Speech therapy Vocal Polyp (Option A): Vocal polyps are typically unilateral , not bilateral, and arise from sudden vocal trauma rather than chronic abuse. Laryngeal Papilloma (Option C): Papillomas are usually unilateral , cause wart-like growths, and are associated with the HPV virus . They do not typically present as bilateral nodular lesions from chronic vocal strain as in the case provided. Reinke's Edema(Option D) involves bilateral swelling of the vocal cords but is caused by chronic smoking or vocal misuse, presenting as diffuse oedema rather than discrete nodules. The patient's symptoms suggest a localized lesion, making this less likely.

questions.question: A 5 y/o boy presents with a history of progressive hoarseness and stridor. Laryngoscopy reveals multiple warty lesions in the larynx. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Juvenile-onset laryngeal papillomatosis Explanation: Juvenile-onset laryngeal Papillomatosis is the correct answer because it typically presents in young children with multiple lesions and symptoms like hoarseness and stridor, caused by HPV 6 and 11. M / C benign larynx tumor with premalignant potential. Caused by HPV6 and HPV11 There are two types of papillomas. Aspect Juvenile-Onset Laryngeal Papillomatosis Adult-Onset Laryngeal Papillomatosis Age Infants and young children 30-50years Sex No sex predisposition. More common in males. Mode of transmission Mother to child during vaginal delivery Sexual intercourse. Number Multiple Single Location Mostly the supraglottic and glottic regions. But can also involve the subglottis, trachea and bronchi. Anterior half of vocal cord or the anterior commisure. Presentation Hoarseness, aphonia, respiratory difficulty and stridor. Change in voice (initial), airway obstruction, respiratory distress and stridor. Aggressive Aggressive, recurrence is common after excision. Less aggressive does not recur after excision. Recurrence rate High Low Treatment of Laryngeal Papillomas: Surgical : CO2 laser excision during microlaryngoscopy (avoiding vocal ligament injury). Alternative : Removal with cup forceps or debrider if no CO2 laser. Medical Adjuvants : Interferon alpha-2a : Effective but with side effects (fever, chills, myalgia, etc.). 13-cis-retinoic acid : Alternative with significant side effects. Vocal Polyp (Option B): Vocal polyps are typically unilateral and occur in adults with sudden vocal strain, not children with progressive hoarseness and multiple lesions. Adult-Onset Laryngeal Papillomatosis (Option C): This condition occurs in adults (30-50 years) and typically involves single lesions , not multiple warty lesions as seen in this pediatric patient. Vocal Nodule (Option D): Vocal Nodules are bilateral, associated with chronic vocal abuse , and usually occur in adults or professionals with voice strain, not in children with multiple lesions and stridor.

questions.question: A 50 y/o man with a history of chronic cough and weight loss presents with hoarseness and severe throat pain. Laryngoscopy reveals ulcerative lesions predominantly in the posterior part of the larynx, with some areas of hyperemia and swelling. His chest X-ray shows cavitary lesions. Based on the patient's history and laryngeal findings, which condition is most likely responsible for the observed laryngeal lesions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Tuberculosis of the Larynx Explanation: Tuberculosis of the Larynx is the most likely diagnosis due to the presence of ulcerative lesions in the posterior larynx and cavitary lung lesions, indicative of pulmonary tuberculosis. Tuberculosis of the Larynx Lupus of larynx Features Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. Affects middle-aged males. Spread occurs via bronchogenic or haematogenous routes. Tubercle bacilli from sputum settle in laryngeal mucosa, leading to infection Indolent tubercular infection associated with lupus of the nose and pharynx. Lupus primarily affects the anterior part of the larynx. Pathology : Affects the posterior larynx more than the anterior. Common sites: interarytenoid fold, ventricular bands, vocal cords, and epiglottis. Formation of submucosal tubercles, which may ulcerate and cause cellular infiltration (pseudoedema). Starts in the epiglottis , which may be destroyed. Lesion spreads to the aryepiglottic folds and ventricular bands . No association with pulmonary tuberculosis Clinical Features : Weakness of voice (early symptom) Hoarseness Severe pain, radiating to ears, especially with ulceration Dysphagia in later stages. Painless condition. Often asymptomatic, found incidentally during lupus evaluation. Signs : Hyperaemia of vocal cords (impaired adduction) Swelling in inter arytenoid region with a mamillated appearance Ulceration of vocal cords (" mouse-nibbled" appearance ) Superficial ragged ulcerations on arytenoids and inter arytenoid region Granulation tissue in inter arytenoid region Pseudoedema of the epiglottis (" turban epiglottis" ) Swelling of ventricular bands and aryepiglottic folds The pallor of the surrounding mucosa Destruction of the epiglottis. Involvement of aryepiglottic folds and ventricular bands. Diagnosis : X-ray of chest Sputum examination for tuberculosis Biopsy of laryngeal lesion to exclude carcinoma Routine laryngeal examination in patients with lupus of the nose . No pulmonary TB involvement. Treatment : Treat the pulmonary tuberculosis (antitubercular drugs). Voice rest Antitubercular drugs . The prognosis is generally good. Laryngeal Papillomatosis (Option A): Typically involves multiple, less ulcerative lesions and is not usually associated with cavitary lung lesions. Reinkeâ€™s Edema (Option B): Characterized by vocal cord swelling, not typically associated with ulcerative lesions and cavitary lung findings. Lupus of the Larynx (Option C): Affects the anterior larynx and is usually asymptomatic; not associated

questions.question: A 45 y/o woman with a history of heavy smoking presents with a low-pitched, rough voice and noticeable hoarseness. Laryngoscopy reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Reinkeâ€™s Edema Explanation: Reinkeâ€™s Edema is the most likely diagnosis due to the presence of fusiform swelling of the vocal cords with a pale, translucent appearance as shown in the image. It is also consistent with the h/o chronic smoking. Causes : Chronic vocal cord irritation (voice misuse, heavy smoking). Aka smokers larynx Chronic sinusitis, laryngopharyngeal reflux. Myxoedema More common in middle-aged men and women. Clinical Features : Hoarseness or husky voice. Use of false vocal cords for voice production, leading to a low-pitched, rough voice. Examination : Laryngoscopy: Fusiform swelling of vocal cords with a pale, translucent appearance. Ventricular bands may be hyperaemic and hypertrophic, obscuring true cords. Treatment : Decortication of vocal cords : Removal of a strip of epithelium, first on one side, then the other after

questions.question: A 50 y/o man with a history of tobacco chewing presents with a white patch on his laryngeal mucosa which is not easy to scrape off. Oral examination reveals a smooth white patch with no red or ulcerative areas. The patient reports no significant pain or symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's oral lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Leukoplakia Explanation: The presence of a smooth white patch on the laryngeal mucosa without ulceration in patients with h/o tobacco chewing suggests a diagnosis of leukoplakia. Definition White patch on oral mucosa, defined clinically, excluding conditions like lichen planus, candidiasis, etc. Causes Smoking, tobacco chewing Alcohol abuse (especially with smoking) Chronic trauma (ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites) Associated with submucous fibrosis, hyperplastic candidiasis, Plummer-Vinson syndrome Common sites Buccal mucosa (most common in India) Oral commissures, floor of mouth, tongue, gingivobuccal sulcus, lip mucosa Age & Gender Men in their 40s are 2-3 times more affected than females. Clinical types Homogenous : Smooth or wrinkled white patch, lower malignancy risk Nodular (speckled) : White patches on an erythematous base, higher malignancy risk Erosive (erythroleukoplakia) : Interspersed with red patches, fissures, highest malignancy risk Malignant potential 1-17.5% risk, average 5% malignant transformation Higher risk in dysplastic lesions and certain locations Treatment Remove causative factors : Spontaneous regression in some cases. Biopsy : For lesions with high malignant potential. Surgical excision or laser/cryotherapy : For suspicious or small lesions Oral Candidiasis (Option A): Typically presents with white, creamy patches that can be easily scraped off. Lichen Planus (Option C): Often presents with white, lace-like striations (Wickhamâ€™s striae) rather than a smooth white patch. Oral submucous Fibrosis (Option D): Typically presents with oral mucosal stiffness and restricted mouth opening, not a white patch.

questions.question: A 55 y/o man, who is a heavy smoker and drinker, visits complaining of a persistent husky voice and throat irritation. During a laryngoscopic examination, the following is observed. Based on the above image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pachyderma Laryngitis Explanation: The image shows bilateral vocal cord oedema with hypervascularity. Pachyderma , characterised by mucosal thickening, swelling, ulceration and hypertrophy in the arytenoid region, is observed in the posterior glottic space. Pachyderma Laryngitis: A chronic hypertrophic laryngitis Aspect Details Clinical Presentation Hoarseness or husky voice. Throat irritation. Laryngoscopic Findings Red or grey granulation tissue in the interarytenoid region. Ulcerations on the posterior thirds of the vocal cords (contact ulcers). Bilateral and symmetrical changes. Malignant Potential Typically does not progress to malignancy. Biopsy is essential to rule out carcinoma or tuberculosis. Aetiology The exact cause is uncertain. Predominantly in men who smoke and consume excessive alcohol. Contributing Factors Excessive and forceful talking. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), leads to irritation from acidic stomach fluids. Treatment Removal of Granulation Tissue: Performed microsurgically, may require multiple sessions. Acid Reflux Management: Includes lifestyle changes, medications, or surgery. Speech Therapy: Focuses on proper voice techniques and reducing vocal strain. Vocal Polyps (Option B) are usually unilateral , appearing as pedunculated or sessile lesions on the free edge of the vocal cords. They are often associated with phonotrauma (excessive voice

questions.question: A 3 y/o child presents with a 2-day history of a worsening cough, fever, and difficulty breathing. The parents report that the child's cough has a characteristic "barking" quality, and they have noticed increased difficulty in breathing, especially at night. The child appears irritable and distressed. O/E there are signs of respiratory distress. An anteroposterior X-ray of the neck is done. Based on the clinical presentation and X-ray findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis) Explanation: The X-ray given shows the characteristic Steeple sign . The "steeple sign" on the X-ray and the characteristic barking cough are indicative of croup. Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Epiglottitis vs. Croup Aspect Acute Epiglottitis Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis) Diagnosis Visualisation: Red and swollen epiglottis (avoid indirect laryngoscopy to

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding acute epiglottitis compared to croup?

options.A: Acute epiglottitis is more commonly caused by viral infections.
options.B: Croup typically has an abrupt onset and rapid progression.
options.C: The "thumb sign" on a lateral neck X-ray is a characteristic of croup.
options.D: Acute epiglottitis in children can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Acute epiglottitis in children can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Acute Epiglottitis vs. Croup: Feature Acute Epiglottitis Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis) Cause Haemophilus influenzae type B (most common in children) Viral infections (Parainfluenza types I and II most common) Onset Abrupt onset, rapid progression Starts as an upper respiratory infection with hoarseness and a "croupy" cough then progress down to larynx l/t barking cough Incidence Affects children 2â€“7 years old; can also occur in adults More common, affects children 6 monthsâ€“3 years old (more common in males) Symptoms Sore throat, dysphagia , salivary drooling and tripod posture (Adults) Dyspnoea, stridor, rapid airway obstruction (respiratory emergency in Children) Mild and slow progression as compared to acute epiglottitis. Hoarseness, croupy cough, difficulty breathing, inspiratory stridor, suprasternal and intercostal retractions (severe cases). Fever High fever (up to 40Â°C), often with septicaemia Mild to moderate fever Diagnosis Visualisation of red, swollen epiglottis "Thumb sign" on lateral X-ray of the neck. Avoid indirect laryngoscopy Differentiated from epiglottitis by clinical features, no "thumb sign" A steeple sign is seen on the X-ray. X-Ray Imaging Tripod Position in Acute Epiglottitis: Sitting up on hands, with the tongue out and the head forward. Opens the airway and improves respiratory mechanics. A classic sign of respiratory distress, often indicating life-threatening conditions like acute epiglottitis.

questions.question: Which of the following features is a characteristic of the infant larynx compared to the adult larynx?

options.A: The larynx is positioned opposite the C5 vertebra at rest.
options.B: The thyroid cartilage has a well-defined angle.
options.C: The subglottis is the narrowest part of the larynx.
options.D: The arytenoid cartilages are smaller and cover less of the posterior glottis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The subglottis is the narrowest part of the larynx. Explanation: In infants, the subglottis is the narrowest part, important for paediatric airway management. Differences Between Adult and Infant Larynx: Feature Infant Larynx Adult Larynx Position Higher in the neck; glottis at C3-C4 at rest, C1-C2 during swallowing (allows simultaneous breathing & swallowing) (Option A ruled out) Lower in the neck; vocal cords at the level of C5 vertebra Cartilage Consistency Softer and more prone to collapse Firmer, less prone to collapse Epiglottis Shape Omega ( â„¦ )-shaped Leaf-shaped Arytenoid Size Proportionally larger, covers more of the posterior glottis (Option D ruled out) Smaller compared to infant Thyroid Cartilage Flat, overlaps cricoid cartilage and hyoid bone (narrows cricothyroid and thyrohyoid spaces) (Option B ruled out) A more defined angle does not overlap cricoid cartilage Larynx Shape and Size Smaller, conical; subglottis is the narrowest part Larger, cylindrical; glottis and subglottis are similar in size Submucosal Tissue Looser, more prone to oedema, risk of obstruction Denser, less prone to oedema Growth Spurts Two growth spurts: 1st during the first 3 years (width and length), 2nd in adolescence (vocal cord growth, voice changes) Larynx growth complete after adolescence Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Page 335

questions.question: Which of the following is a paired hyaline cartilage of the larynx?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Arytenoid Explanation: The arytenoid cartilages are paired hyaline cartilages. They are located on top of the cricoid cartilage and are crucial for vocal cord movement and voice production. Larynx- Anatomy The larynx is in front of the hypopharynx, roughly opposite the third to sixth cervical vertebrae. It moves up and down and back and forth during swallowing and speaking. It can also be moved from side to side, which creates a grating feeling known as laryngeal crepitus. In adults, the larynx extends down to the lower border of the C6 vertebra. Type of Cartilage Paired Cartilage Unpaired Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage (Calcifies with age) Arytenoid Thyroid (Option D ruled out) , Cricoid Elastic Cartilage Corniculate, Cuneiform (Option A & C ruled out) Epiglottis Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Page 331 Scott-Brownâ€™s Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery , 8th Edition, 3rd Volume, Pagess 884, 885. Logan Turnerâ€™s Diseases Of Nose, Throat And Ear Head and Neck Surgery, 11th edition. Pages 149, 150

questions.question: Which of the following extrinsic muscles is not an elevator of the larynx?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Sternohyoid Explanation: The sternohyoid muscle is an extrinsic muscle of the larynx which is a depressor, not an elevator of the larynx. It acts to lower the hyoid bone and the larynx. EXTRINSIC MUSCLES OF THE LARYNX Connect the laryngeal cartilages to the hyoid bone above and the trachea below. ELEVATORS DEPRESSORS Primary elevators (Option B ruled out) Act directly as they are attached to the thyroid cartilage. Stylopharyngeus Salpingopharyngeus Palatopharyngeus Thyrohyoid Sternohyoid Sternothyroid Omohyoid Secondary elevators (Options C & D ruled out) Act indirectly as they are attached to the hyoid bone. Mylohyoid (main) Digastric Stylohyoid Geniohyoid Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Pages 332, 333 Logan Turnerâ€™s Diseases Of Nose, Throat And Ear Head and Neck Surgery, 11th edition. Page 151 Scott-Brownâ€™s Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery , 8th Edition, 3rd Volume, Pages 887, 888

questions.question: Which of the following intrinsic muscles of the larynx is a tensor and is derived from the 6th branchial arch?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cricothyroid Explanation: The cricothyroid muscle is a tensor of the vocal cords and is derived from the 6th branchial arch. Branchial arch Laryngeal Structure 4th arch Thyroid cartilage All muscles except cricothyroid (Option A, C & D ruled out) 6th arch Arytenoids, corniculate, cricoid and tracheal cartilages Cricothyroid muscle Hypobranchial eminence Epiglottis INTRINSIC MUSCLES OF THE LARYNX Acting on the vocal cord Acting on the Laryngeal inlet Abductors Posterior cricoarytenoid(Safest muscle of larynx) Openers of the laryngeal inlet Thyroepiglottic Adductors Lateral cricoarytenoid Interarytenoid (unpaired muscle , dual nerve supply by right and left RLN)(transverse arytenoid) Thyroarytenoid (external part) Closers of laryngeal inlet Interarytenoid (oblique part) Aryepiglottic (posterior oblique part of inter arytenoids) Tensors Cricothyroid Vocalis (internal part of thyroarytenoid)

questions.question: What type of epithelium lines the vocal cords, and what is the space between them called?

options.A: Non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium; Rima vestibularis
options.B: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium; Rima glottidis
options.C: Non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium; Rima glottidis
options.D: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium; Rima vestibularis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium; Rima glottidis Explanation: The vocal cords are lined by non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium and the space between them is called the rima glottidis. LARYNGEAL CAVITY The laryngeal cavity extends from the laryngeal inlet aryepiglottic fold to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, where it continues with the trachea. It is divided into three parts by two pairs of folds, the vestibular and vocal folds : Vestibule : Located between the laryngeal inlet and the vestibular folds, its anterior wall is the epiglottis, the sides are the aryepiglottic folds, and the posterior wall is formed by the mucosa covering the arytenoids. Ventricle (Sinus of Larynx) : A space between the vestibular and vocal folds. It contains the saccule , a mucosal diverticulum that lubricates the vocal cords. An abnormal enlargement of the saccule can form a laryngocele . Subglottic Space : Extends from the vocal cords to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. The rima vestibularis is the space between the vestibular folds (Option A & D ruled out) , while the rima glottidis is the narrowest part of the larynx, located between the vocal folds. It is divided into an anterior phonatory portion and a posterior respiratory portion. Mucous membranes of the larynx: Pseudostratified Ciliated Columnar Epithelium (Respiratory-Type): Most of the larynx. Non-Keratinizing Stratified Squamous Epithelium: Upper Half of the Posterior Surface of the Epiglottis Upper Part of the Aryepiglottic Fold Posterior Glottis Vocal Folds (Vocal Cords) (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: Match the following: 1. Extrinsic Membranes of Larynx a) Quadrangular membrane 2. Intrinsic Membranes of the larynx b) Aryepiglottic membrane c) Thyrohyoid membrane d) Cricothyroid membrane e) Cricovocal membrane
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1- c, d; 2- a, b, e Explanation: Extrinsic Membranes Intrinsic Membranes Connecting laryngeal cartilage to extra laryngeal structure. Connecting laryngeal cartilage to another laryngeal cartilage. Thyrohyoid membrane - Pierced by superior laryngeal vessels and internal laryngeal nerve. Cricothyroid membrane - Pierced in a cricothyroidotomy during access for an emergency airway Hyoepiglottic ligament - Connects epiglottis to the hyoid bone. Aryepiglottic membrane - Completely seals off the laryngeal spaces, creating a sphincter that protects the larynx and lungs from foreign bodies. Quadrangular membrane - The lower border forms the vestibular ligament which forms the false cord. Cricovocal/ Conus elasticus membrane - Connects the thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid cartilages, forming the vocal ligament and conus elasticus. It provides a site where subglottic foreign bodies may become impacted.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the arytenoid, corniculate, and cuneiform cartilages?

options.A: The arytenoid cartilages have a base that articulates with the cricoid cartilage.
options.B: The corniculate cartilages articulate with the apex of the arytenoid cartilages.
options.C: The cuneiform cartilages provide support to the vocal cords.
options.D: The corniculate cartilages are responsible for supporting the aryepiglottic fold.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The cuneiform cartilages provide support to the vocal cords. Explanation: Cuneiform cartilages are rod-shaped and located in the aryepiglottic fold, but they provide support to the aryepiglottic fold, not the vocal cords. The vocal cords are attached to the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilages. CARTILAGE DESCRIPTION ARYTENOID Paired Hyaline Cartilage. Each arytenoid cartilage is shaped like a pyramid. Base : The base of each arytenoid cartilage articulates with the cricoid cartilage. (Option A ruled out) Muscular Process : A lateral projection where intrinsic laryngeal muscles attach. Vocal Process : Anterior projection that provides attachment for the vocal cords. Apex : The top part of the arytenoid cartilage that supports the corniculate cartilage. CORNICULATE Cartilages of Santorini There are two corniculate cartilages, one on each side. Elastic cartilage Each corniculate cartilage articulates with the apex of the arytenoid cartilage. (Option B ruled out) They resemble horns (hence the name "corniculate") and function to support the aryepiglottic fold. (Option D ruled out) CUNEIFORM Cartilages of Wrisberg Paired elastic Cartilage. Each cuneiform cartilage has a rod-like shape. Positioned in the aryepiglottic fold in front of the corniculate cartilage. Provides passive support to the aryepiglottic fold, enhancing its stability.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the epiglottis?

options.A: It is an unpaired hyaline cartilage.
options.B: Preepiglottic space is not associated with cancers involving the base of the tongue.
options.C: It is connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament.
options.D: It is NON essential for swallowing and cannot be safely removed.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It is connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament. Explanation: The epiglottis is connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament. Epiglottis Unpaired Elastic Cartilage (Option A ruled out) Shape: Leaf-shaped yellow elastic cartilage. Location: Forms the anterior wall of the laryngeal inlet. Attachments: Connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament , dividing it into suprahyoid and infrahyoid portions. The petiole attaches it to the thyroid cartilage just above the vocal cords. Anterior Surface: Preepiglottic Space: Located in front of the epiglottis, between the anterior surface and the thyrohyoid membrane/upper thyroid cartilage. Filled with fat, it may be involved in supraglottic cancers or the base of tongue carcinomas. (Option B ruled out) Posterior Surface: Tubercle of Epiglottis: A bulge that may obstruct the view of the anterior commissure during indirect laryngoscopy. Contains pits for mucous glands and occasional perforations, which may facilitate cancer spread to the preepiglottic space. Clinical Significance: Cancer Spread: Supraglottic cancers can invade the pre-epiglottic space through epiglottic perforations. Non-Essential for Swallowing: The epiglottis can be safely amputated in cases of cancer or trauma without significant risk of aspiration. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Page 331 Scott-Brownâ€™s Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery , 8th Edition, 3rd Volume, Pages 886, 887. Logan

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with hoarseness of voice and breathing difficulties following minor neck trauma. During evaluation, imaging reveals calcified structures in the laryngeal region. What is the most likely cause for this finding?

options.A: Displacement of the thyroid cartilage from its normal position
options.B: Formation of fibrous tissue in the cricoid cartilage
options.C: Inflammatory changes in the arytenoid cartilage

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Age-related ossification of cricoid cartilage Explanation: The cricoid cartilage, made of hyaline cartilage , tends to calcify as part of the aging process, typically beginning around 25 and completing by 65, leading to changes seen on imaging. Cricoid Cartilage Complete ring : The only laryngeal cartilage forms a full ring, resembling a signet ring with a broader posterior lamina and a narrow anterior arch. Articulations : Forms the cricothyroid joint with the thyroid cartilage, allowing rotation along a transverse axis. Forms the cricoarytenoid joint with the arytenoid cartilages, permitting rotational and gliding movements, which control vocal cord motion. Attachments : The cricotracheal membrane connects it to the first tracheal ring. The cricovocal membrane attaches to its arch, forming the vocal ligament. Clinical relevance : In children, the cricoid cartilage is smaller in diameter than the glottis, making it the narrowest part of the airway, crucial for choosing the correct endotracheal tube size. Calcification in older adults can appear as a foreign body on X-rays. Subglottic foreign bodies may lodge near the cricoid cartilage, especially in children. Displacement of the thyroid cartilage from its normal position (Option A): Displacement of the thyroid cartilage, such as dislocation from the cricoid, is not suggested by the presence of calcified structures on imaging. Formation of fibrous tissue in the cricoid cartilage (Option B): The cricoid cartilage is primarily hyaline cartilage, and fibrous tissue is not a typical finding.it can be associated with prolonged ET tube insertion Inflammatory changes in the arytenoid cartilage (Option C): Inflammatory conditions of the arytenoid cartilage might cause vocal cord dysfunction or airway obstruction, but would not lead to calcified structures in the cricoid cartilage.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the thyroid cartilage is correct?

options.B: The alae of the thyroid cartilage meet at an angle of 120Â° in males.
options.C: It is an unpaired hyaline cartilage.
options.D: Foreign bodies are typically arrested below the vocal cords

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It is an unpaired hyaline cartilage. Explanation: The thyroid cartilage is an unpaired hyaline cartilage of the larynx. Thyroid Cartilage The thyroid cartilage is the largest cartilage in the larynx. (Option A ruled out) It is an unpaired hyaline cartilage of the larynx. (Option C) It has two alae (wings) that meet at an angle: 90Â° in males and 120Â° in females. (Option B ruled out) The vocal cords are attached to the middle of this thyroid angle. Most foreign bodies in the larynx get trapped above the vocal cords above the middle of the thyroid cartilage. (Option D ruled out) An emergency airway can be created by piercing the cricothyroid membrane, a procedure known as cricothyrotomy. Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Page 331 Scott-Brownâ€™s Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery , 8th Edition, 3rd Volume, Pages 885, 886. Logan Turnerâ€™s Diseases Of Nose, Throat And Ear Head and Neck Surgery, 11th edition. Page 150
